articles.headline: Uber Releases Diversity Report and Repudiates Its ‘Hard-Charging Attitude’
articles.snippet: The report, which excludes drivers, showed Uber’s employees are overwhelmingly male and the largest ethnic group is white, though the figures are not so different from other tech companies.
articles.abstract: The report, which excludes drivers, showed Uber’s employees are overwhelmingly male and the largest ethnic group is white, though the figures are not so different from other tech companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After a string of scandals this year, Uber has rushed to repair its corporate culture. The ride-hailing company has started an internal investigation into workplace practices, issued apologies for some of its behavior, and has had several female executives and a board member speak up on its behalf.

articles.headline: U.S. ‘Probably Had a Role’ in Mosul Deaths, Commander Says
articles.snippet: The remarks by a general were the fullest acceptance of responsibility by an American commander for a March 17 strike that killed scores of civilians.
articles.abstract: The remarks by a general were the fullest acceptance of responsibility by an American commander for a March 17 strike that killed scores of civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The senior United States commander in Iraq said on Tuesday that an American airstrike most likely led to the collapse of a building in Mosul that killed scores of civilians this month.

articles.headline: At BlackRock, Machines Are Rising Over Managers to Pick Stocks
articles.snippet: BlackRock is merging many actively managed mutual funds with peers that rely more on algorithms and models to pick stocks.
articles.abstract: BlackRock is merging many actively managed mutual funds with peers that rely more on algorithms and models to pick stocks.

articles.headline: Policy Shift Helps Coal, but Other Forces May Limit Effect
articles.snippet: Reversing clean power rules may lead to more drilling and pipelines, but economics and state initiatives still favor natural gas and renewable energy.
articles.abstract: Reversing clean power rules may lead to more drilling and pipelines, but economics and state initiatives still favor natural gas and renewable energy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many fossil fuel executives are celebrating President Trump’s move to dismantle the Obama administration’s Clean Power Plan. But their cheers are muted, because market forces and state initiatives continue to elevate coal’s rivals, especially natural gas and renewable energy.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Diane Cardwell

articles.headline: Amid White House Tumult, Pence Offers Trump a Steady Hand
articles.snippet: As other advisers floundered in recent weeks, the vice president has emerged as an effective wingman for a president short on competent help.
articles.abstract: As other advisers floundered in recent weeks, the vice president has emerged as an effective wingman for a president short on competent help.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When some of President Trump’s aides were reassuring him over the past few weeks that he had enough votes to pass a health care bill, Vice President Mike Pence was skeptical.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Westinghouse Files for Bankruptcy, in Blow to Nuclear Power
articles.snippet: The company, whose corporate parent is Toshiba of Japan, led projects once seen as heralding a nuclear renaissance, but its filing casts a pall over the troubled industry.
articles.abstract: The company, whose corporate parent is Toshiba of Japan, led projects once seen as heralding a nuclear renaissance, but its filing casts a pall over the troubled industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Westinghouse Electric Company, which helped drive the development of nuclear energy and the electric grid itself, filed for bankruptcy protection on Wednesday, casting a shadow over the global nuclear industry.
articles.byline: By Diane Cardwell and Jonathan Soble

articles.headline: China Poised to Take Lead on Climate After Trump’s Move to Undo Policies
articles.snippet: For years, the United States pushed China to commit to limiting its use of fossil fuels. The countries now look likely to switch roles.
articles.abstract: For years, the United States pushed China to commit to limiting its use of fossil fuels. The countries now look likely to switch roles.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, the Obama administration prodded, cajoled and beseeched China to make commitments to limit the use of fossil fuels to try to slow the global effects of climate change.

articles.headline: Meet the Everyday People Who Have Sued Trump. So Far, They’ve Won.
articles.snippet: Plaintiffs suing President Trump to block his travel ban have included professors and grocery clerks, Americans and people trying to become one.
articles.abstract: Plaintiffs suing President Trump to block his travel ban have included professors and grocery clerks, Americans and people trying to become one.
articles.lead_paragraph: The papers each bore two names, one unknown, the other ubiquitous, facing off across the letter V. The V was important. It meant that in America, anyone could sue the president of the United States and hope to win.

articles.headline: Pillars of the West Shaken by ‘Brexit,’ but They’re Not Crumbling Yet
articles.snippet: Britain’s withdrawal from the E.U. and Donald J. Trump’s election are blows to multilateralism, but many European nations seem to be shying away from going it alone.
articles.abstract: Britain’s withdrawal from the E.U. and Donald J. Trump’s election are blows to multilateralism, but many European nations seem to be shying away from going it alone.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — On a day that blended dull ritual with undeniable historical import, Britain formally began its departure from the European Union with the delivery of a letter to Brussels, followed by lofty words from Prime Minister Theresa May in Parliament.
